By WILLIAM H. HOWELL,

To his old companions in the
Medical School the sudden death
of Dr. Mall brings a feeling of inexpressible regret; sorrow for the
loss of a personal friend who
shared intimately and helpfully
in the work and play of daily life
and a full realization that the
common enterprise in whose success we are so greatly interested
has been deprived of the services
of one of its strongest supporters.
In the spring of 1893 the first
meeting of the fully organized faculty of the new Medical School
was held in the library of the McCoy house on Eutaw Place, then
occupied by President Gilman and
now owned by Dr. Finney—Gilman, Remsen Osler, Welch, Halsted, Kelly, Mall, Abel and Howell formed the group that met to
discuss the policy of the school
and to arrange some of the details
of the curriculum for the first
year. Oilman was the oldest of
the group and Mall the youngest.
These two only have been called
away—death made its first selections at the two ends of the line.
Before the opening of the Medical School, Mall had been a member of the University. During the
sessions of 1886-89 he was one of
that fortunate band who gathered
round Dr. Welch in the pathological laboratory attached to the hospital. Untroubled by class duties
or routine tasks they lived an ideal
university life, learning from one
another as well as from their distinguished leader, and. devoting
themselves whole-heartedly to the
.kind of research work which at
that time was somewhat rare in
this country. Among this group
of able men, some of whom have
since risen to the highest rank,
Mall was recognized as one of the
most gifted in those qualities that
go to make a successful investigator. It was therefore practically a matter of course that when
the opportunity came to the University to inaugurate a medical department Mall should be selected
as one of the members of the new
faculty. He had meanwhile filled
positions at Clark University when
first organized and subsequently
at the newly founded University
of Chicago. It was a period of
great activity in the development
of facilities for the higher education in this country and the fact
that Mall, a young man just turning his thirties, was asked to join
each of these three important new
movements is significant testimony to the reputation that he

HOPKINS GIVES STATE TERRIFIC BATTLE
THAT TAKES ALL STING FROM DEFEAT
STATE WINS CONTEST BY NARROW MARGIN
Hopkins Fights Off Heavy and Confident State Team and Holds
Them to One Touchdown—Black and Blue Defense Uncannily
Powerful—Sadler a Gritty and Capable Pilot—Winslow's
Place Kick Wide By Inches—Team Plays Best
Game of Year.
Hopkins gave State the surprise of her life on Thanksgiving
Day. In a terrific battle in which she was heavily outweighed but
never outplayed nor outfought, Hopkins held the big State team
to a single touchdown and refused to concede a victory to her traditional rival until the final whistle brought the 1917 season to a
close. State was never more confident of defeating Hopkins and
yet never had to fight harder to retain her laurels as football champion of Maryland. Hopkins was desperate and fighting mad; State
was heavy and confident. Hopkins was defeated, but certainly not
disgraced.
Hopkins started off like a house afire, she swept her heavy opponents
off their feet and rushed the ball to State's 20-yard line before State
came to. When the State line stiffened, Winslow dropped back for a
place-kick, Jones holding the ball. It was a difficult angle, but the
ball sailed straight for the goal posts only to miss them by a couple
of inches. That narrow escape brought State to her feet; it made her
realize that she was up against a tough proposition. State took the
ball on her own 20-yard line and marched down the field with grim
determination to score a touchdown. It was Fletcher, the brilliant
back of the Farmer aggregation, that carried the ball over. During
the rest of the half, Hopkins outplayed State and kept the play well
into her opponent's territory, but never could take the ball within
scoring distance. Sadler was used up badly by the State ends and
backs, but stuck it out gamely; he ran the team with snap and precision and was easily the star for the local team.
The second half found both teams fighting desperately for the advantage and was featured by the constant exchange of punts. Jones'
vicious tackles were the outstanding feature of the play, until. Hopkins made that heroic stand on her 3-yard line just before the whistle
blew. The Hopkins team played about 100 per cent. better than it
has played in any game this year, and fought like demons for every
inch of ground. Besides Sadler and Jones, Sheffey and Stanley played
brilliantly for the Black and Blue.

Rothschild Succeeds Carroll as Third
Editor-in-Chief of this Year—Carroll
Stansbury Elected to New Office
of Managing Editor.

At the weekly meeting of THE
NEWS-LETTER Board on last Monday, Morton K. Rothschild '18,
was elected to succeed Mitchell B.
Carroll, whose application for a
commission in the Aviation Corps
has been accepted, as editor-inchief Of THE NEWS-LETTER, and
Carroll Stansbury, '20, was elected to the new office of managing
editor. Rothschild is the third
man to serve as editor-in-chief of
THE NEWS-LETTER since the resignation of Reuben Oppenheimer,
'17, last May. Henry Evans '18,
w o was elected to succeed
'Op-h
penheimer, was at the time of his
election driving an ambulance in
France and was granted leave of
absence by the Board until the
first of November when he expected to return to the University. At
the expiration of his term of six
months as ambulance driver, however, he applied for a commission
in the United States Army and
passed an examination for a second lieutenancy in the field artillery, so he remained in France.
Mitchell B. Carroll,'19, who had
served as assistant editor last
year and as managing editor in
the absence of Evans, was elected
to succeed Evans. Carroll was
eminently prepared to take over
the duties of editor - in - chief
through his long training as as-.
sistant editor and managing editor. But it was not long before
he announced to the Board that
his application for service in the
Flying Corps had been accepted
and that he would be obliged to
relinquish the office of editor-inchief.
The new editor-in-chief is a
member of the Senior Class and
was elected an assistant editor
only a month ago. Up to this
time, he has been chiefly interested in debating, having served as
chairman of the junior debating
team and as a member of the 'Varsity team last year; he was also
the winner of the Adams medal
in 1916. He is now president of
the Debating Council, chairman of
the senior debating team,and was
recently initiated into the Hopkins
Circle of Omicron Delta Kappa.
He was also a member of the 1918
Hullabaloo Board, from which he
resigned when the class voted to
overrule the board and publish a
Hullabaloo in spite of the war.
Stansbury served as assistant
editor under Carroll and as managing editor in Carroll's absence,
and is therefore well acquainted

BALTIMORE, MD., DEC. 3, 1917.
Another Change.

The period of uncertainty and
confusion, incidental to the declaration of war last spring, seems
to re-echo down the restless history of THE NEWS-LETTER this
year. Since the resignation last
May of one of the most capable,
liberal and successful editors of
THE NEWS-LETTER, no less than
three men have succeeded to the
office of editor-in-chief, the war
having called two of them away
almost immediately after they
were elected. THE NEWS-LETTER
believes that it is a great tribute,
rather than a misfortune, that it
should have been placed in the
hands of such patriotic, self-denying men that they could relinquish their high office to enter the
service of their country. Henry
C. Evans and Mitchell B. Carroll
have been denied the exercising of
an honored privilege that was due
them, but only for the reason that
they might perform a greater service--a service to their country.
It is with peculiar regret, and
yet with pride, that THE NEWSLETTER has been obliged to forego
the leadership of such men as
Evans and Carroll. It regrets, for
anxiety for its own welfare; it is
proud, for love of its country.
Evans had a wealth of experience
in e'ditorial work, was a prominent member of the Senior Class,
and would have had six months'
active service on the western front
when he expected to return to the
University this fall. Carroll had'
edited THE NEWS-LETTER in the
absence of Evans and was well
fitted to succeed Evans when he
decided to remain in France.
So THE NEWS-LETTER has been
brought to realize that our country is at war and that war is all
that Sherman claimed for it. Not

only has it been deprived of two
most promising and eminently
qualified editors, but also has its
staff of associate editors been reduced by almost one-half. To tide
over the critical, condition in
which THE NEWS-LETTER has been
left, it has been deeided to introduce a new system. The office
of managing editor has been made
permanent and will be filled by

This is a recent letter from Edward 0. Hulburt, who took the
degree of A. B. here in 1911 and
the degree of Ph. D. in 1915. He
was for a time captain of the lacrosse team. Recently he has been
employed in the physics laboratory of the Westinghouse Lamp
Company at Bloomfield, N. J.
Last September he enlisted in the
Signal Corps and received a first
lieutenant's commission. He arrived in France about November 1.
THE NEWS-LETTER is indebted to
Dr. L. S. Hulburt, professor of
mathematics and father of "Eddie" Hulburt, for the publication
of this vividly interesting letter.
It is as follows:
DEAR FATHER:
This is our first day out, and I
will start now and write a few
lines. We cannot mention names,
places or dates, so that I will have
to leave blanks and give general
statements.
We have some troops and a number of unattached officers on board,
and in company with some other
boats are ,being convoyed across.
My room mate, E. H. Walker,
first lieutenant in the Ordnance
Department, is a very pleasant
fellow and we shall get along
famously.
Last night all the officers were
assembled and given a talk on the
precautions necessary. No lights
at all are allowed after dark—no
smoking outside—you can smoke
in your rooms but must light up
down below. This morning while
at breakfast Walker and I were
ordered to the bridge as lookouts.
We had an uneventful two-hour
watch. Little did I ever suppose I
should be standing on the bridge
watching for evidences of submarines. We congratulated ourselves upon being on a transport
where we are given a share in the
work—this would perhaps not
have happened had we been on a
regular liner.
Our schedule is two hours on the
bridge and six hours off. This
gives us 8 A. M. to 10 A. M., then
again 4 P. M. to 6 P. M. and finally midnight to 2 A. M. As far as
we know now this keeps up for the
remainder of the trip.
This morning we had a life belt
drill and were assigned stations
at the life rafts. We watched the
men practicing passing ammunition, and watched the guns being
oiled and prepared for action. Retired early, at 8 P. M., because
there were no lights. On watch
again at midnight—it is rather impressive to see the dim outlines of
the other ships of our convoy all
gliding along without lights. Was
not relieved until 2.40—the next
man overslept.
Next Day. Nothing of interest
happened—clear, blue sky, hard
south wind, warm, perhaps near
gulf stream. At the midnight
watch found a sky and sea black
as ink, with a warm wind from

the south, almost a gale. I don't
understand why it is so warm—I
-would think we were taking a
southerly course—but as far as I
know we have been coming directly east. At night we have nary a
light, and we have to pick our way
through lines of sleeping soldier
boys—they all sleep on deck out in
the open in good weather.
This morning we found that two
transports and a destroyer had become separated from us during the
ni.g,ht. A few hours after daylight
we found them waiting for us—
they had gotten ahead in the dark.
It is a clear, warm, sparkling Sunday—and the men are singing and
skylarking around—they seem to
have gotten most of their sea legs
now. We read magazines—we appreciate the people who put stamps
on them and sent them to us—
there must be about a cart load of
literature on board—it is a blessing to everyone.
This afternoon we heard that we
were to pick up a convoy of warships soon — the officers' mess
abounds with rumors—perhaps we
are much further south than New
York—this would account for the
warm weather—but we don't
know; we don't know our destination.
Next Day. This morning a man
went overboard from our flagship,
we all went slowly while they went
to pick him up. I hope they got
him, but don't know. In the afternoon had lecture on military tactics am! a French conversation
class.
Next Day. This morning we
found that one of our transports
had left us—rumor says it went
back because of a leak. In the
afternoon the cruiser had target
practice, it fired several broadsides of six-inch guns—a great
sight, looked just like the pictures.
We are having cooler weather now
—just like the days in Maine. I
am getting very tanned by the
wind. The meals are excellent and
Walker (my room mate) and I eat
prodigiously. The indications now
are that we aren't south, but are
in about the latitude of New York
and are pursuing a direct route
across.
Next Day. This morning we
sighted an oil tank steamer—one
of our destroyers ran over to sniff
at its heels and find out what it
was doing—these little destroyers
are like little dogs, the way they
run around and nose into everything. More lectures and French.
We get news by wireless from both
sides of the ocean. There are many
congenial men on board—Hedlund.
who keeps watch with me, is a
graduate of Dartmouth and has
been doing graduate work in mathematics at Illinois. He is second
lieutenant in the Adjutant General's Department. Rained during
afternoon -and night watches.

eventful has happened. We still
pursue our leisurely course across

another as well as from their distinguished leader, and. devoting

.kind of research work which at

BALTIMORE, MD., DEC. 3, 1917.
Another Change.

The period of uncertainty and
confusion, incidental to the declaration of war last spring, seems
to re-echo down the restless history of THE NEWS-LETTER this
year. Since the resignation last
May of one of the most capable,
liberal and successful editors of
THE NEWS-LETTER, no less than
three men have succeeded to the
office of editor-in-chief, the war
having called two of them away
almost immediately after they
were elected. THE NEWS-LETTER
believes that it is a great tribute,
rather than a misfortune, that it
should have been placed in the
hands of such patriotic, self-denying men that they could relinquish their high office to enter the
service of their country. Henry
C. Evans and Mitchell B. Carroll
have been denied the exercising of
an honored privilege that was due
them, but only for the reason that
they might perform a greater service--a service to their country.
It is with peculiar regret, and
yet with pride, that THE NEWSLETTER has been obliged to forego
the leadership of such men as
Evans and Carroll. It regrets, for
anxiety for its own welfare; it is
proud, for love of its country.
Evans had a wealth of experience
in e'ditorial work, was a prominent member of the Senior Class,
and would have had six months'
active service on the western front
when he expected to return to the
University this fall. Carroll had'
edited THE NEWS-LETTER in the
absence of Evans and was well
fitted to succeed Evans when he
decided to remain in France.
So THE NEWS-LETTER has been
brought to realize that our country is at war and that war is all
that Sherman claimed for it. Not

only has it been deprived of two
most promising and eminently
qualified editors, but also has its
staff of associate editors been reduced by almost one-half. To tide
over the critical, condition in
which THE NEWS-LETTER has been
left, it has been deeided to introduce a new system. The office
of managing editor has been made
permanent and will be filled by
• Carroll Stansbury, '20. The managing editor will have charge of
all current news and be responsible for what is known as the
"makeup" of the paper, while the
editor will be responsible for the
editorials and the general policy
of the paper. Stansbury served as
assistant editor under Carroll,
and as managing editor since Carroll has been called from college;
he has shown that he is entirely
capable of his new functions. THE
NEWS-LETTER, in spite of its "wartorn" board and inexperienced
editor-in-chief, aims to be worthy
of the honor Evans and Carroll
brought it and to live up to the
high standard and noble traditions of the past.
Dr. Mall.

An appreciation of Dr. Mall,
whose services to the Medical
School were recently brought to
such an untimely end, appears
elsewhere in these columns under
the name of a man who knew Dr.
Mall personally and professionally, and who knew how to appreciate him. It is not for us to
supplement Dr. Howell's tribute.
But we cannot help but feel that,
separate as we are from the Medical School, the loss of Dr. Mall
is our loss, too. Another great
man, one of the builders of Hopkins' world-wide reputation, has
been taken away. Following the
recent demise of Dr. Clark, the
death of Dr. Mall marks the second great extra-war loss the University has suffered in the last few
months.
A Glorious Defeat.

It isn't exactly good form to
glory in defeat, and we frankly
admit that we would have greatly
preferred to beat State and beat
them badly. But, as a second
choice, we could not have asked
for greater satisfaction than what
we derived from our defeat on
Thanksgiving Day. Never has a
Hopkins team fought harder, untold handicaps notwithstanding,
to win a football game. Every
single man on that team gave
everything that was in him and a
whole lot more, and "Dick" Woodward may be proud to have led
a team that was second to none in
spirit and fight and sportsmanship. The University honors the
men that fought the greatest battle ever staged on Homewood
Field: Woodward, Sadler, Sheffey, Jones, Stanley, Schmidt,Winslow, Hecht, McKeithen, Carey,
Katencamp, Wolfe, Cashell, Calkins. Boys, we're mighty damned
proud of you!

This is a recent letter from Edward 0. Hulburt, who took the
degree of A. B. here in 1911 and
the degree of Ph. D. in 1915. He
was for a time captain of the lacrosse team. Recently he has been
employed in the physics laboratory of the Westinghouse Lamp
Company at Bloomfield, N. J.
Last September he enlisted in the
Signal Corps and received a first
lieutenant's commission. He arrived in France about November 1.
THE NEWS-LETTER is indebted to
Dr. L. S. Hulburt, professor of
mathematics and father of "Eddie" Hulburt, for the publication
of this vividly interesting letter.
It is as follows:
DEAR FATHER:
This is our first day out, and I
will start now and write a few
lines. We cannot mention names,
places or dates, so that I will have
to leave blanks and give general
statements.
We have some troops and a number of unattached officers on board,
and in company with some other
boats are ,being convoyed across.
My room mate, E. H. Walker,
first lieutenant in the Ordnance
Department, is a very pleasant
fellow and we shall get along
famously.
Last night all the officers were
assembled and given a talk on the
precautions necessary. No lights
at all are allowed after dark—no
smoking outside—you can smoke
in your rooms but must light up
down below. This morning while
at breakfast Walker and I were
ordered to the bridge as lookouts.
We had an uneventful two-hour
watch. Little did I ever suppose I
should be standing on the bridge
watching for evidences of submarines. We congratulated ourselves upon being on a transport
where we are given a share in the
work—this would perhaps not
have happened had we been on a
regular liner.
Our schedule is two hours on the
bridge and six hours off. This
gives us 8 A. M. to 10 A. M., then
again 4 P. M. to 6 P. M. and finally midnight to 2 A. M. As far as
we know now this keeps up for the
remainder of the trip.
This morning we had a life belt
drill and were assigned stations
at the life rafts. We watched the
men practicing passing ammunition, and watched the guns being
oiled and prepared for action. Retired early, at 8 P. M., because
there were no lights. On watch
again at midnight—it is rather impressive to see the dim outlines of
the other ships of our convoy all
gliding along without lights. Was
not relieved until 2.40—the next
man overslept.
Next Day. Nothing of interest
happened—clear, blue sky, hard
south wind, warm, perhaps near
gulf stream. At the midnight
watch found a sky and sea black
as ink, with a warm wind from

the south, almost a gale. I don't
understand why it is so warm—I
-would think we were taking a
southerly course—but as far as I
know we have been coming directly east. At night we have nary a
light, and we have to pick our way
through lines of sleeping soldier
boys—they all sleep on deck out in
the open in good weather.
This morning we found that two
transports and a destroyer had become separated from us during the
ni.g,ht. A few hours after daylight
we found them waiting for us—
they had gotten ahead in the dark.
It is a clear, warm, sparkling Sunday—and the men are singing and
skylarking around—they seem to
have gotten most of their sea legs
now. We read magazines—we appreciate the people who put stamps
on them and sent them to us—
there must be about a cart load of
literature on board—it is a blessing to everyone.
This afternoon we heard that we
were to pick up a convoy of warships soon — the officers' mess
abounds with rumors—perhaps we
are much further south than New
York—this would account for the
warm weather—but we don't
know; we don't know our destination.
Next Day. This morning a man
went overboard from our flagship,
we all went slowly while they went
to pick him up. I hope they got
him, but don't know. In the afternoon had lecture on military tactics am! a French conversation
class.
Next Day. This morning we
found that one of our transports
had left us—rumor says it went
back because of a leak. In the
afternoon the cruiser had target
practice, it fired several broadsides of six-inch guns—a great
sight, looked just like the pictures.
We are having cooler weather now
—just like the days in Maine. I
am getting very tanned by the
wind. The meals are excellent and
Walker (my room mate) and I eat
prodigiously. The indications now
are that we aren't south, but are
in about the latitude of New York
and are pursuing a direct route
across.
Next Day. This morning we
sighted an oil tank steamer—one
of our destroyers ran over to sniff
at its heels and find out what it
was doing—these little destroyers
are like little dogs, the way they
run around and nose into everything. More lectures and French.
We get news by wireless from both
sides of the ocean. There are many
congenial men on board—Hedlund.
who keeps watch with me, is a
graduate of Dartmouth and has
been doing graduate work in mathematics at Illinois. He is second
lieutenant in the Adjutant General's Department. Rained during
afternoon -and night watches.
Three Days Later. Nothing
eventful has happened. We still
pursue our leisurely course across
the Atlantic, averaging 250 to 300
miles a day. Our daily routine

To the Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:

Sir—Why isn't battalion football given more support? At
present there are about a dozen
men out for each team and several
of these fail to show 'up for the
games. The consequence is that
just before a game the little group
of players has to plead with the
few on the side lines to get in the
game and help them out. By this
means a full eleven is usually
drafted, but two weeks ago one
of the teams actually started the
game with ten men.
Fellows, this isn't the right
spirit. It is a privilege—and, even
if not considered so, your duty—
to play on your company team.
The present squads should at
least be doubled, and if it is impossible for you to play you
should at least show your company loyalty by rooting.
The apathetic little band of
rooters expends what little energy
it has in kidding the players along
or at best in urging their team to
victory with disorganized and extemporaneous cheers or some bewhiskered witticisms. Why not
elect a yell leader from each company? Then, with the adherents
of one company on one side line
and their opponents on the other,
there will be some good oldfashioned Hopkins yelling.
The freshmen especially should
be on hand to get practice in
cheering and to get up more enthusiasm in the inter-company
sports. Battalion athletic competition is the father of 'Varsity success, so let's get behind it and develop a wealth of material for the
big team. The freshmen can be
forced to attend these games whenever possible as well as the 'Varsity games. Wake up, men! Mr.
Kistler's movement, launched
through the medinnt of the battalion. is the biggest thing yet
and W ill exert a tremendous influence of the athletic welfare and
good fellowship at the University.
Are you heart and soul behind it?
